queries.company_overview:
Cloudflare, Inc. operates a global connectivity cloud that secures and accelerates Internet applications, networks, and developer workloads at the edge, including AI inference. Its unified, software-only platform runs across a large worldwide network, providing security, performance, and developer services through one control plane.
- Application Services: CDN, WAF, DDoS, Bot Management, API security
- Zero Trust/SASE (Cloudflare One): Access, Gateway/SWG, CASB, RBI, Email Security
- Network Services: Magic Transit, Magic WAN, Interconnect/Peering
- Developer Platform: Workers, Pages, R2, D1, Vectorize, Queues
- AI Platform: Workers AI and AI Gateway for serverless model inference
High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $1.6696B; FY2024 GAAP net loss $78.8M (USD). Market capitalization $79.23B as of 2025-10-29 (USD).
Competitive positioning: Competes with Akamai and Fastly in application delivery/security; with Zscaler, Palo Alto Networks, Cisco, and Fortinet in Zero Trust/SASE; and with hyperscalers and edge platforms (AWS CloudFront/Lambda@Edge, Azure, Google, Vercel, Netlify) for developer and edge workloads. Differentiation includes an integrated platform spanning security, networking, and developer services on a large global network (330+ cities) with a single control plane; independent, verified market share is Unknown.
Recent major news:
- 2025-10-14 Cloudflare collaborates with leading payments companies to secure and enable agentic commerce.
- 2025-10-13 Cloudflare integrates services with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure to enhance applications and AI workloads.
- 2025-06-13 Cloudflare prices $1.75B of 0% convertible senior notes due 2030.
- 2025-04-11 Cloudflare launches Workers VPC and VPC Private Link for secure cross-cloud applications.
- 2025-02-06 Cloudflare reports FY2024: revenue $1.6696B; GAAP net loss $78.8M.

What is Cloudflare's current net revenue.query: What is Cloudflare's current net revenue retention rate and trajectory among customers spending over $100,000?
What is Cloudflare's current net revenue.answer: Cloudflare’s current net revenue retention (dollar-based net retention) is 114% as of Q2 2025, up 3 percentage points sequentially, indicating re-acceleration. Among customers spending over $100,000 annually, momentum is strong: the large-customer cohort grew 22% year over year to 3,712 and contributed 71% of revenue, with management noting these largest customers are increasing investments at the highest levels since 2022.

search_results.title: Cloudflare, Inc. (NET) Q2 2025 Earnings Call – Corrected Transcript
search_results.snippet: Management reported Q2 2025 dollar-based net retention of 114%, up 3 percentage points sequentially and 2 points year over year. The company ended the quarter with more than 3,700 customers spending over $100,000 annually, up 22% YoY; large customers contributed 71% of revenue, with record additions in the $1M+ and $5M+ cohorts, underscoring accelerating expansion.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Announces Second Quarter 2025 Financial Results
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare highlighted that demand remains strong as its largest customers are growing their investments at the highest levels since 2022. Revenue grew 28% YoY to $512.3 million and the company surpassed $2 billion in annualized revenue, signaling strengthening momentum among its biggest accounts.

search_results.title: Q4 2024 Investor Presentation
search_results.snippet: Key business metrics show dollar-based net retention trending from 117% in Q1’23 to 111% in Q4’24, while paying customers over $100,000 increased to 3,497 and represented 69% of revenue by Q4’24. This provides context for the subsequent Q2 2025 re-acceleration and expanding contribution from large customers.

What near-term roadmap has Cloudflare pu.query: What near-term roadmap has Cloudflare published for Workers AI model availability and performance upgrades?
What near-term roadmap has Cloudflare pu.answer: Cloudflare’s near-term roadmap for Workers AI focuses on expanding model availability while accelerating inference. It is rolling out more powerful GPUs across its global network (now 180+ cities) to support larger models like Llama 3.1 70B and Llama 3.2 11B vision, publishing TTFT/TPS targets, and adding optimizations such as KV cache compression and speculative decoding for 2–3× higher throughput and 40–70% faster generation. On availability, Cloudflare is broadening its catalog with a ‘Run Any* Model’ closed beta (with private instances planned) and, from launch, committed to scaling GPUs from 7 sites to ~100 by end‑2023 and nearly everywhere by end‑2024, alongside per‑model analytics/observability.

search_results.title: Cloudflare’s bigger, better, faster AI platform
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare outlines near‑term upgrades to Workers AI: deploying more powerful GPUs across its network (now 180+ cities) to cut latency and enable larger models (e.g., Llama 3.1 70B and Llama 3.2 11B vision), publishing TTFT/TPS metrics, and expanding availability via a new ‘Run Any* Model’ dynamic catalog in closed beta while keeping a curated catalog ‘warm’; it also shifts to simpler unit‑based pricing.

search_results.title: Making Workers AI faster and more efficient: Performance optimization with KV cache compression and speculative decoding
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare details performance upgrades for Workers AI—new GPUs, an open‑source KV cache compression technique, and speculative decoding—aimed at near‑term speed gains, with reported 2–3× throughput improvements on Llama 3.1/3.2 and 40–70% faster generation, signaling ongoing optimizations to reduce TTFT and raise tokens‑per‑second.

search_results.title: Workers AI: serverless GPU-powered inference on Cloudflare’s global network
search_results.snippet: At launch Cloudflare published its near‑term plan for Workers AI: scale GPUs from 7 sites to roughly 100 by end‑2023 and ‘nearly everywhere’ by end‑2024 to deliver low‑latency inference, add per‑model analytics/observability, and integrate a subset of the Hugging Face catalog directly into Workers AI to rapidly broaden model availability.

Where is Cloudflare winning large SASE d.query: Where is Cloudflare winning large SASE deals versus Zscaler and Palo Alto Networks in 2025?
Where is Cloudflare winning large SASE d.answer: In 2025, Cloudflare’s largest SASE wins are concentrated in the public sector and regulated enterprises across the U.S., EMEA, and APAC. Examples include a five‑year $5.1M SASE consolidation at a large U.S. state government (replacing a “first‑generation Zero Trust” vendor), multi‑year SASE deployments with a U.S. federal entity, an international critical‑infrastructure provider, and European quasi‑government agencies. Management also cites strong traction in financial services and critical infrastructure, alongside EMEA and APAC growth—i.e., places where Cloudflare often competes head‑to‑head with Zscaler (first‑gen Zero Trust) and Palo Alto Networks’ firewall‑centric SASE.

It also cites a Fortune 500 tech Zero Trust win after the customer returned from a first‑gen vendor. The CFO highlights ‘green shoots’ in public sector and financial services, with EMEA up 29% YoY and APAC up 44%, indicating where Cloudflare is taking SASE share.

Cloudflare notes outperforming a ‘first‑generation’ competitor and displacing multiple vendors—evidence of where it’s winning SASE against incumbent stacks.

This supports that Cloudflare’s 2025 SASE wins skew toward regulated enterprise sectors—where it frequently competes head‑to‑head with Zscaler and Palo Alto Networks.

How will Cloudflare monetize its new NET.query: How will Cloudflare monetize its new NET Dollar initiative across products and regions in 2026?
How will Cloudflare monetize its new NET.answer: Cloudflare has indicated it will monetize NET Dollar by taking fees on transactions that traverse its new ‘Act 4’ agentic-payment rails, embedded across its network and product surface (e.g., API/Workers pay-per-call, content access, and agent-to-agent microtransactions). Management is prioritizing adoption through 2025, with pricing to follow, and is using open standards like x402 and the Agent Payments Protocol to enable cross-product, cross-border usage “across currencies, geographies, and time zones” in 2026.

search_results.title: Cloudflare, Inc. (NET) Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript (Corrected)
search_results.snippet: On the Q2 2025 call, CEO Matthew Prince said Cloudflare expects to earn fees on transactions running over its new Act 4 agentic-payment rails as agents pass through its network, while focusing near term on adoption and supporting multiple protocols—setting up usage-based monetization embedded across products in 2026.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Introduces NET Dollar to Support a New Business Model for the AI-Driven Internet
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare positions NET Dollar to power pay-per-use, microtransactions, and fractional payments for the agentic web—enabling creators, developers, and AI agents to monetize APIs and content with instant, programmable payments that work across currencies, geographies, and time zones via open standards (Agent Payments Protocol, x402).

search_results.title: Cloudflare Unveils U.S. Dollar Stablecoin for AI-Powered Internet Economy
search_results.snippet: CoinDesk reports Cloudflare will launch NET Dollar, a USD-backed stablecoin to enable instant, global AI-agent payments and microtransactions; CEO Matthew Prince framed this as a shift away from ads and bank transfers toward per-use payments as the internet’s core model—implying transaction-driven monetization as the network scales.

What pricing changes has Cloudflare impl.query: What pricing changes has Cloudflare implemented for Zero Trust seat bundles or usage tiers during 2025?
What pricing changes has Cloudflare impl.answer: In 2025, Cloudflare updated its Zero Trust Service-Specific Terms to set and enforce a per-seat usage cap for Gateway DNS: 150,000 DNS queries per seat per month (5,000/day), with monitoring and mandatory seat top-ups if the cap is exceeded. Public pricing for seats remained structured as Free ($0, up to 50 users) and Pay‑as‑you‑go ($7/user/month, paid annually) with Enterprise custom pricing, positioning Standard for teams over 50 users (effectively establishing a 50‑seat threshold when moving beyond the free tier). Cloudflare’s 2025 docs also codify plan-based usage tiers (e.g., DEX tests and remote capture quotas differ by Free/Standard/Enterprise), reflecting formalized usage limits tied to seat plans.

search_results.title: Service-Specific Terms - Cloudflare (Zero Trust Services)
search_results.snippet: Last updated Aug 11, 2025, Cloudflare’s Zero Trust terms define per-seat licensing and set an Average Monthly DNS Queries limit for Gateway DNS of 150,000 per seat (5,000/day). Usage is monitored monthly and exceeding the cap allows Cloudflare to require purchase of additional seats, clarifying 2025 enforcement of per-seat usage thresholds.

search_results.title: Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) solution - Cloudflare
search_results.snippet: The Access pricing section shows the 2025 seat structure: Free ($0, up to 50 users), Pay‑as‑you‑go at $7 per user/month (paid annually), and Contract (custom per user). The page positions Standard for teams over 50 users, implying a 50‑seat threshold when upgrading beyond the free tier while keeping per‑seat pricing unchanged.

search_results.title: Account limits - Cloudflare Zero Trust docs
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare’s 2025 account limits page documents plan-based usage tiers, such as Digital Experience Monitoring limits (DEX Tests per account: Free 10, Standard 30, Enterprise 50; Remote captures per day: Free 100, Standard 200, Enterprise 800). These quotas illustrate usage limits tied to Zero Trust plan tiers for 2025.

What recent Cloudflare service outages o.query: What recent Cloudflare service outages or security incidents affected SLA commitments, and what mitigations were deployed?
What recent Cloudflare service outages o.answer: Cloudflare’s most recent SLA-impacting events include a June 12, 2025 outage (2h28m) that took down Workers KV and many dependent paid services, a February 6, 2025 R2 outage (59m) caused by a mistaken product disablement, and a June 20, 2024 edge incident that spiked CDN errors and latency. Mitigations included disabling offending rules and redeploying services, global restarts and traffic rebalancing, feature kill‑switches and graceful degradation to shed load, adding admin guardrails and two‑party approvals, and accelerating migration of Workers KV to more resilient backends along with backbone capacity improvements.

search_results.title: Cloudflare service outage June 12, 2025
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare reported a 2h28m outage on 2025-06-12 where Workers KV failed due to a third‑party storage backend, cascading to Access, WARP/Gateway, Images, Stream, Workers AI, Turnstile, and parts of the dashboard; mitigations included kill switches to avoid blocking users, shedding identity/device‑posture requests, graceful degradation of rules, working to run KV on an alternative datastore, and accelerating migration of KV’s central store to R2 as services recovered.

search_results.title: Cloudflare incident on February 6, 2025
search_results.snippet: On 2025-02-06, human error during abuse remediation disabled the R2 Gateway, causing 59 minutes of 100% R2 API failure and heavy impact on dependent services (Stream, Images, Cache Reserve, Vectorize, logs); recovery required re‑enabling/redeploying the gateway and follow‑ups added admin API guardrails, restricted product disablement, two‑party approvals, improved internal account tagging, and better observability and health‑check automation.

search_results.title: Cloudflare incident on June 20, 2024
search_results.snippet: Two concurrent events on 2024-06-20—backbone congestion from suboptimal re‑routing and a new HTTP DDoS rule exposing a latent rate‑limiting bug—caused up to 2.1% CDN error responses and 3x p99 TTFB for about 114 minutes; Cloudflare mitigated by restarting services, disabling the DDoS rule, using Traffic Manager to reroute load, and committing code fixes plus capacity and rebalancing improvements to prevent similar process poisoning and congestion.

How will Cloudflare's Oracle Cloud Infra.query: How will Cloudflare's Oracle Cloud Infrastructure integration change go-to-market motions and shared customer deals?
How will Cloudflare's Oracle Cloud Infra.answer: By making Cloudflare’s connectivity cloud available natively on OCI, Oracle sellers can more easily co-sell Cloudflare into hybrid/multicloud and AI workloads, backed by Oracle’s partner program benefits like training, enablement, and go-to-market collaboration. For shared customers, Oracle’s Bandwidth Alliance participation with Cloudflare provides zero egress for OCI Object Storage traffic and private interconnections between the networks, lowering total cost and reducing deal friction—creating stronger packaging, pricing leverage, and faster deployment for joint solutions.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Integrates Services with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure to Help Customers Supercharge Applications and AI Workloads
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare announced its connectivity cloud will be available natively on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, letting joint customers use Cloudflare’s security, performance, and resiliency directly from OCI across hybrid, multicloud, and OCI‑hosted apps. The release frames integration around AI and multicloud outcomes and points to Oracle’s partner program—training, enablement, and go‑to‑market collaboration—as the basis for deeper joint selling and solution packaging.

search_results.title: Cloudflare and Oracle Join Forces to Help Eliminate Data Transfer Fees and Ease Path to Multicloud
search_results.snippet: Oracle confirms it joined Cloudflare’s Bandwidth Alliance to waive data transfer fees for mutual customers: data sourced from OCI Object Storage and delivered via Cloudflare carries zero egress (starting in North America, expanding globally). This reduces multicloud costs and removes a key procurement obstacle, strengthening commercial value in shared customer deals.

search_results.title: Oracle - Tech Partners
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare’s Oracle partner page highlights zero egress when using OCI Object Storage with Cloudflare, with traffic moved over private interconnects and peering between the two networks. It positions the pairing as lowering cost while improving performance and security for multicloud deployments—useful for co-sell motions and building compelling joint offers for shared customers.

What compiler or runtime optimizations h.query: What compiler or runtime optimizations has Cloudflare released to reduce AI inference costs on Workers AI?
What compiler or runtime optimizations h.answer: Cloudflare has shipped several runtime optimizations for Workers AI: open-sourced KV cache compression (KV-Compress) integrated with PagedAttention via a vLLM fork to shrink KV memory by up to 8–64x and boost throughput 3.4–5.2x; speculative decoding (prompt-lookup) to pre-generate and verify multiple tokens at once, delivering 2–4x faster inference and 40–70% speedups on Llama models; and prefix (pre-fill) caching plus an updated inference backend to reuse repeated context and better utilize GPU compute. These upgrades increase tokens/sec and GPU utilization, cutting per-token inference costs.

search_results.title: Workers AI gets a speed boost, batch workload support, more LoRAs, new models, and a refreshed dashboard
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare details runtime speedups for Workers AI including speculative decoding, prefix (pre-fill) caching, and an updated inference backend, delivering 2–4x faster inference starting with Llama 3.3 70B. By reusing pre-fill tokens across similar requests and using a small draft model to predict multiple tokens for the base model to verify, GPU utilization improves—reducing latency and per-token costs.

search_results.title: Making Workers AI faster and more efficient - The Cloudflare Blog
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare introduces new runtime techniques: open-source KV cache compression (KV-Compress) that uses PagedAttention to compress per-head KV blocks, retaining >95% task quality at up to 8x compression (and >90% at up to 64x), increasing throughput by 3.44x–5.18x; and speculative decoding (prompt-lookup) that speeds Llama 3.1 models by 40–70%. These reduce memory bottlenecks and compute per token, lowering inference costs.

search_results.title: IsaacRe/vllm-kvcompress: KV cache compression for high-throughput LLM inference
search_results.snippet: An open-source vLLM fork from a Cloudflare researcher showcasing KV cache compression for high-throughput, memory-constrained LLM serving. It evicts contiguous KV blocks within a PagedAttention framework to shrink KV footprint and raise throughput, providing code and instructions to reproduce the compression gains discussed in Cloudflare’s blog and paper.

What patents has Cloudflare filed since.query: What patents has Cloudflare filed since 2024 related to AI inference, model routing, or edge acceleration?
What patents has Cloudflare filed since.answer: Cloudflare filed at least two US patent applications in late 2024 that map directly to Workers AI and AI Gateway. US 2025/0106306 A1 (filed Sept 26, 2024) describes an inference request gateway, a model server that schedules work on GPUs/CPUs, and AI compute routing that selects where to run inference based on latency, cost, and resource availability, with caching, rate limiting, retries, analytics, and safety checks. A companion application, US 2025/0103744 A1 (filed the same day), focuses on proxying requests to external model providers with security rule checks, cache-serve, rate limiting, and logging/analytics—i.e., model routing and edge-accelerated inference control. These filings underpin Cloudflare’s AI Gateway features for dynamic provider/model routing and performance at the edge.

search_results.title: Artificial intelligence service(s) in a distributed cloud computing network
search_results.snippet: US 2025/0106306 A1 (filed 2024-09-26; assignee Cloudflare) details a distributed AI service: an inference request gateway that proxies to internal/external models; a model server that schedules inference on GPU/CPU; and AI compute routing that picks execution sites based on latency, cost, throughput, and compute resource availability (e.g., GPU cycles/memory). It includes caching, rate limiting, retries, analytics, data-locality policies, and jailbreak detection—effectively model routing and inference acceleration at the edge.

How exposed is Cloudflare to attacks fro.query: How exposed is Cloudflare to attacks from state-sponsored actors, and what threat intelligence trends emerged 2025?
How exposed is Cloudflare to attacks fro.answer: Cloudflare has been directly targeted by suspected state-sponsored actors: in late 2023 a ‘likely nation-state’ used stolen Okta credentials to access Cloudflare’s Atlassian (Confluence/Jira/Bitbucket), with no customer impact but prompting a massive ‘Code Red’ remediation (5,000+ credentials rotated, 4,893 systems triaged). In 2025 threat intelligence, activity surged toward malware-free, identity-based intrusions and faster breakouts, with AI-augmented social engineering (notably vishing) rising; China-nexus operations increased sharply, and stolen credentials emerged as a top initial access vector while attackers increasingly targeted SSO, cloud, and unsecured data stores.

The company says access was limited (no customer systems or global network changes), but treated it as an attempt to gain persistent access—rotating 5,000+ credentials, triaging ~4,893 systems, and reimaging its network as part of a ‘Code Red’ hardening effort.

What is Cloudflare's roadmap for Python,.query: What is Cloudflare's roadmap for Python, Rust, and GPU-native libraries within Workers and Workers AI?
What is Cloudflare's roadmap for Python,.answer: Cloudflare’s Python roadmap centers on first‑class Python Workers (via Pyodide in workerd) with built‑in, more “Pythonic” runtime APIs coming next, starting with Workers AI and Vectorize bindings, broader package support, and further cold‑start reductions. For Rust, Workers continues to be supported through workers‑rs, with the SDK moving toward standard http crate types to interoperate with frameworks like Axum—an indicator of ongoing ergonomics and ecosystem alignment rather than a new runtime. For GPU‑native libraries, Workers AI is the forward path: it’s GA with expanding global GPU coverage, BYO LoRA today, and plans for larger models and fine‑tuning; direct GPU access in Workers via WebGPU was previewed for local dev in 2023 but the workerd project later removed the WebGPU API, signaling no near‑term production rollout of GPU APIs inside Workers.

What are Cloudflare's intentions for red.query: What are Cloudflare's intentions for redeeming, repurchasing, or hedging convertible notes due 2026 and 2030?
What are Cloudflare's intentions for red.answer: Cloudflare intends to hedge both its 2026 and 2030 convertible notes using capped call transactions to mitigate dilution and/or reduce any cash payments above principal upon conversion. For the 2026 notes, Cloudflare can optionally redeem for cash on or after August 20, 2024 if the stock trades at least 130% of the conversion price for the required period, and holders have the right to require repurchase at par upon a fundamental change. For the 2030 notes, Cloudflare can optionally redeem for cash on or after June 20, 2028 under the same 130% trigger, with similar fundamental change repurchase rights; it allocated roughly $248 million of proceeds to pay for the capped calls (initial cap about $469.73/share, ~175% premium).

Hyperscalers forgo some egress revenue but gain customer choice, portability, and usage via streamlined, peered connectivity.

ENISA’s 2025 technical guidance operationalizes the Implementing Regulation (EU) 2024/2690 for digital infrastructure providers (including CDNs), clarifying the concrete control expectations Cloudflare and its customers must meet.

How is Cloudflare mitigating geopolitica.query: How is Cloudflare mitigating geopolitical risks impacting network operations in EMEA, APAC, and Latin America?
How is Cloudflare mitigating geopolitica.answer: Cloudflare mitigates geopolitical risk with product, operational, and partnership measures. It expanded Regional Services so customers can strictly control where traffic is decrypted and inspected—including adding regions like Brazil, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Taiwan, and options to exclude Russia/Belarus and Hong Kong/Macau—explicitly in response to geopolitical developments. In conflict zones, Cloudflare has moved encryption keys out of at‑risk countries, uses Keyless SSL, auto‑bricks servers that lose power/connectivity, and enforces a robust sanctions compliance program while maintaining access to information. In APAC, it partners with JD Cloud in China so services run locally under Chinese rules without cross‑border data exposure, helping customers navigate regulatory and political constraints.

search_results.title: Expanding Regional Services configuration flexibility for customers
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare expanded Regional Services so customers can decide where traffic is inspected and, crucially, exclude or include specific jurisdictions. New regions include Brazil (LATAM), Saudi Arabia and South Africa (EMEA), Taiwan and Hong Kong (APAC), plus “Exclusive of Russia and Belarus” and “Exclusive of Hong Kong and Macau” options—added because some customers are reacting to geopolitical developments. This lets organizations keep TLS termination and Layer‑7 security in‑region to meet sovereignty, compliance, and geopolitical risk requirements.

search_results.title: Steps we've taken around Cloudflare's services in Ukraine, Belarus, and Russia
search_results.snippet: During the Russia–Ukraine war, Cloudflare hardened operations by moving customer encryption key material out of Ukraine, Russia, and Belarus; relying on Keyless SSL; and configuring data center servers to auto‑brick if they lose power or connectivity. It also implemented strict sanctions compliance (terminating sanctioned entities, blocking paid access in sanctioned regions) while keeping services available in Russia to preserve access to information—measures aimed at safeguarding network operations and data amid geopolitical conflict in EMEA.

search_results.title: Creating a True One-Stop Solution for Companies to Go Global: Announcing a Partnership Between Cloudflare and JD Cloud & AI
search_results.snippet: To address regulatory and political complexities in China (APAC), Cloudflare partnered with JD Cloud to add extensive in‑country data centers and operate services locally. Cloudflare runs services outside China and JD operates them inside, with no Cloudflare customer traffic passing through China unless explicitly opted in; logs and traffic from outside China are not stored in China. Cloudflare notes it cannot control the trade/political climate but can mitigate risk by helping customers navigate technical, regulatory, and logistical hurdles.

What effective conversion prices and pot.query: What effective conversion prices and potential dilution scenarios exist for Cloudflare's convertible notes outstanding?
What effective conversion prices and pot.answer: Cloudflare’s currently outstanding convertibles are the 0% notes due 2026 and 0% notes due 2030. The 2026 notes have an initial conversion price of about $191.34 per share (5.2263 shares per $1,000) with capped calls that offset dilution up to roughly $250.94. The 2030 notes convert at about $247.67 per share (4.0376 shares per $1,000) with capped calls initially capping dilution at approximately $469.73. Below the conversion prices, no dilution occurs; above them, conversions could add shares unless settled in cash, with the capped calls mitigating dilution up to their cap levels. The earlier 2025 notes (conversion price ~$37.43; cap ~$57.58) matured in May 2025 and are no longer outstanding.

search_results.snippet: Cloudflare’s Regional Services supports EU-wide and multiple Asia regions—including India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong—ensuring TLS termination and Layer 7 services (like WAF and Workers) occur only in the chosen region. What measures is Cloudflare taking to pr.answer: Cloudflare combines ML-driven Bot Management to detect and block content scrapers and other malicious automation without CAPTCHAs, with new AI-focused controls to curb and monetize scraping. AI Crawl Control (formerly AI Audit) gives site owners analytics on AI bots, a one‑click block, WAF policies to allow/deny specific crawlers, and for paid plans the ability to return customizable HTTP 402 “Payment Required” responses and participate in Pay Per Crawl—turning unauthorized scraping into licensed, revenue‑aligned access.

search_results.title: The next step for content creators in working with AI bots: Introducing AI Crawl Control
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare has moved its AI Audit tool to general availability as AI Crawl Control, letting publishers selectively block or allow AI crawlers and, for paid plans, send customizable HTTP 402 “Payment Required” responses. Alongside the Pay Per Crawl initiative, this shifts from blanket blocking to controlled, monetizable access—providing contact/licensing info to crawlers and a pathway to capture value instead of losing traffic and revenue to unlicensed AI scraping.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Bot Management
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare Bot Management uses machine learning, behavioral analysis, and fingerprinting to classify and stop bad bots—including content scraping, credential stuffing, inventory hoarding, and DDoS—while allowing good bots. It assigns bot scores, detects anomalies at scale, and avoids user friction by replacing CAPTCHAs with privacy‑first challenges, helping protect revenue by preventing abusive automated traffic that steals content or degrades user experience.

search_results.title: Start auditing and controlling the AI models accessing your content
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare introduced AI Audit (now AI Crawl Control) to give site owners visibility into which AI services are crawling their content, plus a one-click option to block AI bots and WAF filters to allow specific providers. It also supports exporting reports to audit contractual terms and previews monetization tools to set prices for scans—helping creators reduce unauthorized scraping and recapture value that would otherwise leak as AI platforms repurpose their content.

How is Cloudflare preparing for EU AI Ac.query: How is Cloudflare preparing for EU AI Act compliance across Workers AI and AI Gateway services?
How is Cloudflare preparing for EU AI Ac.answer: Cloudflare is building EU AI Act–aligned safety and governance into its AI stack by adding configurable Guardrails to AI Gateway (powered by Llama Guard on Workers AI) to evaluate prompts and responses, flag/block risky content, and maintain detailed logs for auditing and record‑keeping. AI Gateway also centralizes observability (logs, metrics, token counts), rate limiting, and security controls to manage behavior and compliance across providers, while Workers AI is privacy‑by‑default (no training on customer data) and plans data localization—measures that support EU risk management, transparency, and data governance obligations.

search_results.title: Keep AI interactions secure and risk-free with Guardrails in AI Gateway
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare introduced Guardrails in AI Gateway to standardize content safety across models, citing the EU AI Act’s requirements for risk management, data governance, technical documentation, and record‑keeping. Guardrails use Llama Guard on Workers AI to evaluate prompts and responses, let teams flag or block hazardous categories, and link evaluations to real‑time logs—providing traceability, auditing, and compliance capabilities for AI apps.

search_results.title: An intelligent control plane for your AI applications
search_results.snippet: AI Gateway acts as a unified control plane with built‑in observability (logs, metrics, token counts), caching, rate limiting, and dynamic routing. It highlights safety guardrails and security controls to protect sensitive data and explicitly notes guardrails help manage behavior and compliance across multiple providers—supporting governance and policy enforcement needed for regulatory readiness.

search_results.snippet: Workers AI is described as privacy‑by‑default: Cloudflare says it does not train LLMs on customers’ data or conversations, and models don’t learn from usage. How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust perform.query: How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust performance compare with Zscaler's under real-world latency benchmarks?
How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust perform.answer: Across multiple real‑world, end‑user–focused latency tests, Cloudflare’s Zero Trust consistently outperforms Zscaler. Cloudflare reports its Secure Web Gateway around 58% faster than ZIA and its ZTNA about 38–46% faster than Zscaler at the 95th percentile, with proxy latency often an order of magnitude lower; broader multi‑region tests also show Cloudflare leading on average SWG response times. Independent Miercom testing similarly found Cloudflare’s ZTNA performance ~42% better overall (2× faster internationally; ~16% faster domestically) than competitors including Zscaler.

search_results.title: Cloudflare is faster than Zscaler
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare ran end‑user style benchmarks by deploying side‑by‑side VMs with the Cloudflare WARP client and Zscaler ZIA, measuring 95th‑percentile Time to First Byte and HTTP response times to real sites (Azure‑hosted app, Google, Slack, Zoom). Results show Cloudflare Gateway’s P95 response (≈164 ms) nearly as fast as a no‑proxy control (≈142 ms) and far ahead of Zscaler (≈366 ms), and Cloudflare Access (ZTNA) globally ≈38% faster than Zscaler (P95 TTFB 849 ms vs 1,361 ms). Cloudflare’s P95 proxy latency was ≈7 ms versus Zscaler frequently >100–250 ms, indicating Cloudflare’s SWG is ~58% faster and its ZTNA substantively faster under real‑world conditions.

search_results.title: Spotlight on Zero Trust: we're fastest and here's the proof
search_results.snippet: Expanding to 12 regions and 11 public endpoints, Cloudflare instrumented clients for Cloudflare, Zscaler, Netskope, and Palo Alto and measured 95th‑percentile HTTP metrics. In these broader tests, Cloudflare was 46% faster than Zscaler for ZTNA and 64% faster for RBI, and was the fastest SWG in the most scenarios; across all SWG tests Cloudflare’s P95 response averaged 515 ms vs Zscaler’s 595 ms (~13% faster). Cloudflare attributes the gains to last‑mile proximity and extensive peering that reduce end‑to‑end latency.

search_results.title: Zero Trust Network Access
search_results.snippet: Independent lab Miercom tested Cloudflare’s Zero Trust across domestic and international locations and found Cloudflare delivered better user‑experienced ZTNA and RBI latency than competitors. Key findings: Cloudflare was ~42% better overall for ZTNA and RBI, twice as fast on average internationally for ZTNA, and ~16% faster on average domestically for ZTNA; for RBI, Cloudflare averaged 49% faster internationally. The study used distributed nodes to measure response times representative of real user performance.

What percentage of Cloudflare's traffic.query: What percentage of Cloudflare's traffic benefits from on-net interconnects versus paid transit globally?
What percentage of Cloudflare's traffic.answer: Cloudflare does not publish a single, current global percentage split. Its most detailed public breakdown (2016) shows peering shares ranging from ~40% in North America to ~60% in Europe/South America and ~50% in Oceania, with Africa’s locally served traffic ~90% peered and the Middle East at 100% peered from Cloudflare’s caches; Asia averaged ~60% peered but with outliers like South Korea at 2%. Today, Cloudflare says it interconnects settlement‑free with 12,500+ networks worldwide, indicating the majority of its traffic flows over on‑net interconnects and a minority over paid transit.

search_results.title: Bandwidth Costs Around the World
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare’s regional data shows peering vs transit shares by geography: ~60% of traffic is peered in Europe (~40% transit); ~40% peered in North America; ~60% peered in South America; ~50% peered in Oceania; in Africa, of the traffic served locally, ~90% is peered; in the Middle East, traffic served from Cloudflare’s caches is 100% peered; in Asia, ~60% is peered overall, though outliers exist (e.g., South Korea ~2%). These figures indicate most regions see a majority of traffic delivered via on‑net interconnects rather than paid transit.

search_results.title: Reaffirming our commitment to free
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare explains its cost model relies on extensive settlement‑free interconnection: it operates its own global network, interconnects with more than 12,500 networks, and has hundreds of ISP partnerships that host its servers and peer directly. This broad on‑net footprint lets Cloudflare avoid paying third‑party transit for a large share of traffic while improving performance.

search_results.title: Making peering easy with the new Cloudflare Peering Portal
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare highlights open, settlement‑free peering and notes it peers with over 10,000 networks in 275+ locations. By exchanging traffic directly (public IX and PNIs), networks bypass paid transit paths, cutting costs and latency—evidence that Cloudflare’s traffic is largely carried over on‑net interconnects rather than transit.

How is Cloudflare competing with Fastly.query: How is Cloudflare competing with Fastly Compute and Vercel Edge Functions for developer workloads?
How is Cloudflare competing with Fastly.answer: Cloudflare competes by turning its global CDN into a full developer platform: Workers runs code on its edge with near‑zero cold starts and web‑standard APIs, and bundles primitives like KV, Durable Objects, D1, R2, Queues, Vectorize, Workers AI, and Hyperdrive for database acceleration—letting teams build full‑stack apps without stitching services together. Independent comparisons show Workers and Fastly Compute@Edge offer similar Web Streams APIs and TypeScript/DX, with Workers simpler for outbound fetch and CI/CD. Versus Vercel Edge Functions, Cloudflare leans on default global distribution and cost predictability while still supporting modern frameworks (including Next.js Edge Runtime) to attract frontend workloads.

Developers can build APIs, background jobs, and framework apps (Next.js, Svelte, React, etc.) with built‑in observability and simple deployment.

search_results.title: Serverless Functions: Vercel Edge & Cloudflare Workers Guide

What export control or encryption regula.query: What export control or encryption regulations affect Cloudflare's AI deployments and global developer access?
What export control or encryption regula.answer: Cloudflare’s AI and developer services are governed by U.S. export control laws and sanctions and by encryption controls under the EAR. Cloudflare’s terms prohibit use by parties on U.S./EU/UK sanctions lists and ban using its services to export or re‑export information or technology to restricted countries or entities. For encryption, EAR Category 5, Part 2 applies; most cryptographic functionality can be exported under License Exception ENC (740.17) with required reporting, though some destinations or end users still require licenses. Cloudflare also screens customers and relies on OFAC general licenses that authorize certain Internet/communications services in sanctioned jurisdictions, which can shape availability and access for developers globally.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Self-Serve Subscription Agreement
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare requires users to comply with all laws and bars use by sanctioned or restricted parties (e.g., OFAC SDN, Commerce Entity List, EU/UK lists). It also prohibits using the service to export or re‑export any information or technology to countries, individuals, or entities where such exports are restricted or prohibited—terms that directly constrain global access to Cloudflare services, including AI.

search_results.title: Encryption controls - Learn&Support | Bureau of Industry and Security
search_results.snippet: Under the EAR, encryption items fall under Category 5, Part 2. License Exception ENC (740.17) authorizes most exports of encryption products after reporting/classification, with some items and destinations still requiring licenses. This framework governs how cryptographic features in cloud/AI services can be offered worldwide and where restrictions still apply.

search_results.title: The challenges of sanctioning the Internet
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare states it complies with U.S./UK/EU sanctions, screens customers, and that its Terms prohibit sanctioned parties from using its services. The post explains how OFAC general licenses permit certain Internet/telecom services in sanctioned jurisdictions (e.g., Iran), illustrating how sanctions policy and limited authorizations shape where and how Cloudflare can provide services globally.

What unit economics does Cloudflare repo.query: What unit economics does Cloudflare report for onboarding and supporting a $1 million ARR customer?
What unit economics does Cloudflare repo.answer: Cloudflare frames the unit economics of a $1M ARR customer as: Cost to Book (CTB) — the sales & marketing dollars required to acquire $1 of incremental ARR (i.e., onboarding) — and Cost to Serve (CTS) — delivery, R&D, support, and G&A as a % of ARR over the customer’s lifetime (i.e., supporting) — with attrition used to compute lifetime revenue. In its latest Investor Day, Cloudflare reported a 42% Unit Economic Margin based on these inputs and shows CTB/CTS benchmarking better than SaaS peers. They present these as per-$1 ARR ratios rather than a single dollar figure for a $1M account, but the same economics apply at that scale.

What obligations does Cloudflare have un.query: What obligations does Cloudflare have under DORA for EU financial institutions using its services?
What obligations does Cloudflare have un.answer: Under DORA, Cloudflare’s obligations arise primarily through Article 30 contract requirements that EU financial entities must include with their ICT providers. This means Cloudflare must support customers with clear service descriptions and locations, sub-processor and data-location transparency with change notifications, robust SLAs and performance monitoring, strong security and business continuity, assistance and timely information during ICT incidents, unrestricted audit/access rights (including for competent authorities), participation in TLPT where required, and exit/transition support and regulator-driven termination rights. Cloudflare says many of these are already in its standard terms and provides a DORA mapping; it has not been designated a critical ICT provider, but if designated, it would be subject to direct EU oversight for critical providers.

It states many required clauses are already in Cloudflare’s standard terms and provides a DORA mapping. Cloudflare notes it has not been designated a “critical” ICT third‑party provider, but will support regulated customers’ compliance and cooperate with authorities.

search_results.title: EU- Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) — Cloudflare DORA Mapping
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare’s mapping to DORA Article 30 lists obligations it will contractually meet for financial entities: clear allocation of rights; detailed service descriptions and subcontracting conditions; transparency on processing locations and sub‑processors; strong data security and availability; data access/return and exit/transition support; SLAs and performance targets; assistance and cooperation during ICT incidents; full cooperation with competent and resolution authorities; participation in TLPT; unrestricted audit/access rights (including for regulators); BCP and testing; and regulator‑triggered termination rights.

What steps is Cloudflare taking to align.query: What steps is Cloudflare taking to align with UK NCSC guidance for protective DNS and Zero Trust?
What steps is Cloudflare taking to align.answer: Cloudflare is implementing the UK NCSC’s Protective DNS (PDNS) service with Accenture, delivering a resolver that blocks access to known malicious domains, provides metrics and SIEM integrations, and supports roaming clients over DoH—consistent with NCSC’s PDNS guidance. For Zero Trust, Cloudflare’s platform (Access, Secure Web Gateway, WARP/device posture, DLP, RBI, CASB) enables identity- and policy-driven access, inspection, and monitoring across users, devices, and apps, supporting adoption in line with NCSC’s Zero Trust design principles.

search_results.title: Protective Domain Name Service (PDNS)
search_results.snippet: NCSC’s Protective DNS is a recursive resolver that blocks domains known to be malicious. Created by NCSC and implemented by Cloudflare and Accenture, PDNS is free, mandated for central government, and offers network health metrics and outreach support. It includes PDNS Roaming (Windows, macOS, iOS) using DNS over HTTPS, integrates with SIEMs (connectors for Microsoft Sentinel and Splunk), and does not provide content filtering—only malicious domain blocking.

search_results.title: Protective DNS for governments
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare Gateway delivers protective DNS for office and remote users via location-based IPs and DoT/DoH, enforcing DNS policies backed by Cloudflare threat intelligence. Admins can use custom block pages, integrate agency or third‑party threat feeds, and apply identity‑based policies with the device agent. All DNS queries are logged with dashboard analytics and exportable via Logpush; the service can extend to full SWG capabilities (HTTP inspection, AV scanning, sandboxing, RBI, DLP).

search_results.title: Cloudflare Zero Trust
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare Zero Trust (part of Cloudflare One SASE) replaces legacy perimeters with a unified control plane, combining Access (ZTNA), Secure Web Gateway (DNS/HTTP filtering), WARP for device posture and policy enforcement, Cloudflare Tunnel, Data Loss Prevention, Remote Browser Isolation, CASB, and email security. These capabilities enable identity‑ and policy‑driven access, deep inspection, and monitoring across users, devices, and applications to support Zero Trust adoption.

What contracts does Cloudflare hold for.query: What contracts does Cloudflare hold for dark fiber or wavelength services to extend its private backbone?
What contracts does Cloudflare hold for.answer: Cloudflare does not publicly disclose specific carrier contracts for its backbone. In its own network briefings, Cloudflare states it operates metro dark fiber and leases long‑haul DWDM wavelength services that it buys and leases from multiple global carrier partners to extend its private backbone. Beyond this general disclosure (and recent notes on backbone expansion), no named vendors or contract details are publicly available.

search_results.title: The backbone behind Cloudflare’s Connectivity Cloud
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare explains that its private backbone is a high‑capacity optical fiber network; within cities it manages its own dark fiber, and for long‑distance it leases DWDM wavelengths. It explicitly states these services are bought and leased from global carrier partners. The post also notes a 500% backbone capacity increase since 2021 and that a global ring was completed in 2023 with added subsea capacity to Africa.

search_results.title: Cloudflare Backbone: A Fast Lane on the Busy Internet Highway
search_results.snippet: Cloudflare describes building a dedicated global backbone beginning in 2018, consisting of long‑distance fiber optic links and a metro fiber network interconnecting data centers across regions. The piece emphasizes a private, controlled network for lower latency and reliability, without naming specific transport vendors or contract arrangements.

search_results.title: Cloudflare outage on July 17, 2020
search_results.snippet: In discussing the incident, Cloudflare outlines that its backbone is “a series of private lines between our data centers” used to haul traffic off the public Internet. This confirms the existence of privately provisioned inter‑DC transport but provides no public details on providers or contract terms for dark fiber or wavelengths.

What legal disputes or class actions cur.query: What legal disputes or class actions currently involve Cloudflare products, patents, or alleged service harms?
What legal disputes or class actions cur.answer: Recent Cloudflare legal matters center on a patent suit by Sable Networks, which Cloudflare won at trial in 2024 with a jury finding no infringement and invalidating the asserted claim. In Europe, courts have ordered product-level measures: a German appellate court confirmed Cloudflare’s CDN must block a piracy site, while declining to extend obligations to its 1.1.1.1 DNS resolver. In the U.S., a federal court held Cloudflare’s CDN/caching and security services didn’t materially contribute to copyright infringement, granting summary judgment in Cloudflare’s favor; no prominent consumer class actions over alleged service harms surfaced in current reporting.

search_results.title: Cloudflare defeats another patent troll with crowd-sourced prior-art army
search_results.snippet: A Texas jury in Feb. 2024 found Cloudflare did not infringe Sable Networks’ router patent and also invalidated the final claim that reached trial. The case, filed in 2021 in W.D. Texas, was narrowed through inter partes reviews and Cloudflare’s Project Jengo prior-art effort.

search_results.title: Cloudflare must block piracy site, German court confirms
search_results.snippet: Germany’s Cologne Higher Regional Court upheld an order requiring Cloudflare’s CDN to block the DDL‑Music piracy site, but refused to impose blocking via its 1.1.1.1 DNS resolver, which the court deemed a passive, neutral service. The ruling clarifies Cloudflare’s product-level obligations under German law.

search_results.title: Mon Cheri Bridals v. Cloudflare — Summary Judgment Order (N.D. Cal. 2021)
search_results.snippet: The Northern District of California granted summary judgment to Cloudflare, holding its CDN/caching and security services did not materially contribute to infringement; removing cached content wouldn’t stop access absent host takedown. The decision limits contributory liability claims targeting Cloudflare’s services.

What are Cloudflare's plans regarding po.query: What are Cloudflare's plans regarding potential early refinancing or upsizing of the revolving credit facility?
What are Cloudflare's plans regarding po.answer: Cloudflare has not announced any early refinancing or upsizing of its revolver. The company entered a $400 million senior secured revolving credit facility in May 2024 that already permits an optional increase in commitments of up to $150 million, subject to conditions. Since then, Cloudflare addressed broader financing needs by issuing 2030 convertible notes and amending its credit agreement’s leverage-ratio calculation in June 2025; neither disclosure included a plan to refinance early or upsize the revolver beyond the built-in accordion.

What changes has Cloudflare made to comp.query: What changes has Cloudflare made to compensation structures to retain top-performing enterprise sales talent?
What changes has Cloudflare made to comp.answer: Cloudflare emphasizes performance-based pay to keep its best enterprise sellers. The company standardizes initial offers, then revisits compensation after demonstrated impact to “reward actual accomplishment.” For enterprise AEs, plans use roughly a 51/49 base–variable mix with accelerators that kick in above 100% of quota, creating significant seven‑figure upside for top performers—structures that directly incentivize and help retain high achievers.

search_results.title: CloudFlare Enterprise Account Executive Salary - RepVue
search_results.snippet: RepVue data shows Cloudflare’s enterprise AEs are paid on about a 51/49 base-to-variable mix, with variable tied to bookings/revenue and accelerators that apply once sellers exceed 100% of quota. Top performers can earn $1M+ due to these accelerators, signaling a comp structure built to reward over‑attainment and retain high-performing enterprise sellers.

search_results.title: Why Cloudflare kept salary offers super consistent #techcompanies #startuplife #startups #vc
search_results.snippet: CEO Matthew Prince explains Cloudflare kept initial offers very consistent and then, about six months in, re-evaluated compensation with the expectation of “giving people more,” shifting pay toward “rewarding actual accomplishment.” This philosophy underpins compensating proven top performers to help retain them.

search_results.snippet: Summarizing Prince’s approach, Cloudflare is “at least somewhat inflexible on initial compensation” because it knows the least at the time of hire, but it “quickly reward[s] top performers” thereafter. This performance-first compensation stance supports retaining high achievers once results are proven.

reranked.snippet: Cloudflare announced its connectivity cloud will be available natively on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, letting joint customers use Cloudflare’s security, performance, and resiliency directly from OCI across hybrid, multicloud, and OCI‑hosted apps. The release frames integration around AI and multicloud outcomes and points to Oracle’s partner program—training, enablement, and go‑to‑market collaboration—as the basis for deeper joint selling and solution packaging.

reranked.snippet: On the Q2’25 call, CFO Thomas Seifert reiterated FY2025 network CapEx of 12–13% of revenue and reported Q2 free cash flow of $33.3M (6% margin). He added that management is comfortable with consensus free cash flow estimates for the second half of fiscal 2025, underscoring that FCF will skew to H2.

reranked.snippet: Management linked a step-up in investment to AI inference and GPU rollout, guiding that network CapEx will be 12–13% of revenue in 2025. The commentary frames capex intensity as driven by GPU capacity additions alongside ongoing network expansion.

reranked.title: Cloudflare, Inc. (NET) Q4 2024 Earnings Call – Corrected Transcript (IR PDF)
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare explains that engineering work to drive efficient use of its GPU infrastructure lets Workers AI avoid hyperscaler over‑provisioning (customers would pay ~250% more to stay provisioned) and that inference optimizations on its platform result in faster performance and lower prices for customers—and higher margin and less CapEx for Cloudflare. The company highlights its pay‑per‑inference serverless model as central to these unit‑economics gains.
reranked.query: How will GPU utilization improvements on Workers AI translate into gross margin expansion for Cloudflare?

reranked.title: Cloudflare, Inc. (NET) Q4 2024 Earnings Call (Corrected Transcript)
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare said customers remained disciplined on budgets and scrutinized spend, while growing traction with “pool of funds” platform deals can change the shape of revenue recognition and DNR near term. The quarter also featured multiple financial services wins, including a Global 2000 bank deal and a major international financial institution migrating from a hyperscaler for multi‑cloud and faster provisioning.

reranked.title: Cloudflare Passes 250 Cities, Triples External Network Capacity, 8x-es Backbone
reranked.snippet: After a 3.5× expansion in external network capacity, Cloudflare states that only 30% of the newly doubled capacity was paid transit, with 70% flowing directly via PNIs/CNIs or peering at IXPs. It adds that its private backbone has taken on a “huge amount of traffic” that would otherwise go over external transit and peering, signaling decreased reliance on third‑party transit.
reranked.query: What portion of Cloudflare's network traffic is carried through owned backbone versus third-party transit?

reranked.title: The backbone behind Cloudflare’s Connectivity Cloud
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare explains that its private optical backbone moves traffic between 330+ data centers and carries both internal and external traffic; by operating dark fiber or leased wavelengths it backhauls origin responses and clean traffic, reducing dependency on the public Internet and IP transit. The company says backbone routes are usually lower latency and more cost‑effective than IP transit, and that since 2021 it has increased backbone capacity by more than 500%.
reranked.query: What portion of Cloudflare's network traffic is carried through owned backbone versus third-party transit?

reranked.title: Bandwidth Alliance
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare’s Bandwidth Alliance commits cloud partners to waive or discount egress fees for shared customers, passing savings through and enabling multi‑cloud flexibility. The program highlights discounted paths with Azure and Google (via interconnect programs) and zero‑rated egress with others like Oracle, all delivered over private interconnections and extensive peering to reduce costs and improve performance.
reranked.query: What financial or operational impact do Cloudflare's egress fee waivers have on hyperscaler partnerships?

reranked.title: Cloudflare + Google Cloud Platform
reranked.snippet: Through Google Cloud’s CDN Interconnect, Cloudflare–GCP customers get up to 75% lower egress pricing and faster connectivity via direct interconnects. Case studies on the page cite significant egress-bill reductions, illustrating the financial savings and operational gains from the Cloudflare–Google partnership.
reranked.query: What financial or operational impact do Cloudflare's egress fee waivers have on hyperscaler partnerships?

reranked.title: Cloudflare named in 2024 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Security Service Edge
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare was recognized in the 2024 Gartner Magic Quadrant for SSE for the second year, highlighting rapid capability expansion (DLP, digital experience monitoring, CASB) built on its global edge network; this frames Cloudflare One as a fast‑maturing single‑vendor SASE/SSE option adopted by larger customers.
reranked.query: How is Cloudflare positioned versus Palo Alto Prisma Access for large multinational SASE consolidations?

reranked.title: Zero Trust Network Access
reranked.snippet: Independent lab Miercom tested Cloudflare’s Zero Trust across domestic and international locations and found Cloudflare delivered better user‑experienced ZTNA and RBI latency than competitors. Key findings: Cloudflare was ~42% better overall for ZTNA and RBI, twice as fast on average internationally for ZTNA, and ~16% faster on average domestically for ZTNA; for RBI, Cloudflare averaged 49% faster internationally. The study used distributed nodes to measure response times representative of real user performance.
reranked.query: How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust performance compare with Zscaler's under real-world latency benchmarks?

reranked.title: Spotlight on Zero Trust: we're fastest and here's the proof
reranked.snippet: Expanding to 12 regions and 11 public endpoints, Cloudflare instrumented clients for Cloudflare, Zscaler, Netskope, and Palo Alto and measured 95th‑percentile HTTP metrics. In these broader tests, Cloudflare was 46% faster than Zscaler for ZTNA and 64% faster for RBI, and was the fastest SWG in the most scenarios; across all SWG tests Cloudflare’s P95 response averaged 515 ms vs Zscaler’s 595 ms (~13% faster). Cloudflare attributes the gains to last‑mile proximity and extensive peering that reduce end‑to‑end latency.
reranked.query: How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust performance compare with Zscaler's under real-world latency benchmarks?

reranked.title: Cloudflare is faster than Zscaler
reranked.snippet: Cloudflare ran end‑user style benchmarks by deploying side‑by‑side VMs with the Cloudflare WARP client and Zscaler ZIA, measuring 95th‑percentile Time to First Byte and HTTP response times to real sites (Azure‑hosted app, Google, Slack, Zoom). Results show Cloudflare Gateway’s P95 response (≈164 ms) nearly as fast as a no‑proxy control (≈142 ms) and far ahead of Zscaler (≈366 ms), and Cloudflare Access (ZTNA) globally ≈38% faster than Zscaler (P95 TTFB 849 ms vs 1,361 ms). Cloudflare’s P95 proxy latency was ≈7 ms versus Zscaler frequently >100–250 ms, indicating Cloudflare’s SWG is ~58% faster and its ZTNA substantively faster under real‑world conditions.
reranked.query: How does Cloudflare's Zero Trust performance compare with Zscaler's under real-world latency benchmarks?

reranked.title: Cloudflare Channel Chief On ‘Maximizing’ Partner-Focused Growth Strategy
reranked.snippet: Chief Partner Officer Tom Evans says Cloudflare is making a major 2025 shift to partner‑first, introducing clear rules of engagement for sales, and investing in dedicated pre‑ and post‑sales technical talent across GSIs, service providers, MSSPs, distributors and resellers—specialist resources aimed at deeper collaboration and supporting larger, partner‑led enterprise deals.
reranked.query: What changes has Cloudflare made to sales leadership, enterprise overlays, and specialist teams during 2025?

reranked.title: Cloudflare (NET) Q4 2024 Earnings Call Transcript - The Motley Fool
reranked.snippet: On the Q4 2024 call, management underscored rapid adoption of Workers AI and AI Gateway (e.g., caching-led 10x price-performance) and set 2025 network capex at 12–13% of revenue, but did not quantify AI revenue or give a 2025 contribution figure for these products—reinforcing that guidance is anchored to platform-wide growth rather than a discrete AI line item.
reranked.query: What guidance has Cloudflare given on 2025 revenue contribution from Workers AI and AI Gateway?

report:
# Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: NEUTRAL
- Rating: HOLD
- Next market day view: Range-bound to slightly positive trade as investors digest October partner-program updates and OCI integration. Strong fundamentals (accelerating large-customer expansion, robust RPO, improving FCF cadence) are balanced by a premium valuation and limited near-term catalysts. Expect performance to track broader high-growth software/security peers absent incremental news.

# Executive Summary
Cloudflare is executing well across large-enterprise expansion, public sector momentum, and AI-enabled product adoption, with dollar-based net retention re-accelerating to 114% in Q2-25 and large-customer cohorts compounding faster than overall revenue growth [1]. The company surpassed a $2B annualized revenue run-rate in Q2-25 (revenue +28% YoY) [2], reported robust RPO growth (+39% YoY), and continues to add record-sized and longer-duration deals including its largest contract in company history in Q1-25 [7][11]. Gross margin and FCF should benefit from scale economics (peering/backbone leverage), a low-teens capex envelope (12–13% of revenue), and improving GPU utilization for Workers AI [1][9][10][16][29][31][32].

However, near-term stock performance is likely capped by valuation headwinds and the lack of discrete AI revenue guidance despite strong pipeline and adoption narratives [12][16]. Competitive intensity remains high across SASE and application security, and the 2026 convert maturity represents an eventual capital allocation decision despite available liquidity and new 2030 convert capacity [6][17][18][19].

Net: We see a balanced risk-reward into the next market day and maintain HOLD pending clearer evidence of durable margin expansion from AI workloads and sustained acceleration in large deal flow translating into billings and FCF.

# Company Overview
Cloudflare provides an integrated, software-only connectivity cloud spanning application security and performance (CDN, WAF, DDoS, API security), Zero Trust/SASE (ZTNA, SWG, DLP, CASB, RBI), network services (Magic WAN/Transit), and a developer platform (Workers/Pages/R2/D1/Vectorize) with emerging AI services (Workers AI, AI Gateway). FY2024 revenue was $1.67B with a GAAP net loss of $78.8M; the company surpassed a $2B annualized revenue run-rate by Q2-25 [2]. The platform is deployed globally (330+ cities) with a single control plane.

# Key Findings by Category

## Revenue, Growth, and Retention
- Re-acceleration in large-customer expansion and net retention: Q2-25 dollar-based net retention (DBNRR) improved to 114% (+3 pts QoQ, +2 pts YoY). Customers >$100k ARR exceeded 3,700 (+22% YoY), contributing 71% of revenue; record additions in $1M+ and $5M+ cohorts [1]. Contextually, DBNRR had trended down to 111% by Q4-24 before re-accelerating in 1H-25 [3].
- Run-rate scale and regional breadth: Q2-25 revenue grew +28% YoY to $512.3M, surpassing a $2B annualized run-rate [2]. RPO reached $1.98B (+39% YoY; current RPO +33% YoY). Regional performance: U.S. +22% YoY (49% mix), EMEA +29% (28%), APAC +44% (15%) [11][2].
- Deal sizes and duration expanding: Q1-25 included the largest deal in company history (> $100M, Workers-led) and the longest-term SASE contract to date—signaling rising multi-year adoption [7].

## Monetization Model and Packaging
- Predominantly subscription revenue: Substantially all revenue recognized in Q1-25 was subscription-based; usage-based contributes a small share [6].
- Platform-led bundling and “pool of funds” contracts: Management emphasizes cross-product adoption via pool-of-funds agreements and prescriptive bundles; long-term GM target 75–77% with operating leverage as more products are consolidated per customer [4].
- New packaging to simplify outcomes: Externa (external-facing security/performance) and Interna (Zero Trust/SASE) bundles streamline adoption with predictable per-seat and pooled bandwidth constructs [23].
- Channel program advancements: October 2025 updates added platform solution bundles and material incentives to accelerate partner-led consolidations [22].

## Go-To-Market Execution and Sales Productivity
- Sales capacity and productivity improving: Under new revenue leadership, ramped AEs grew at the fastest pace in two years, sales productivity improved YoY and sequentially, and partner-first motions began to outgrow the rest of the business [1][10][14].
- Hiring: Headcount rose 18% YoY to >4,600, with emphasis on GTM capacity; net sales capacity expected to accelerate in H2-25 [12].
- OCI integration: Cloudflare’s connectivity cloud is available natively on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, enabling deeper co-sell and solution packaging for AI/multicloud workloads [20].

## Competitive Landscape and Wins
- SASE share gains: Public sector and financial services show “green shoots,” with specific takeaways from first-generation Zero Trust vendors; a five-year $5.1M U.S. state deal consolidated multiple tools and reduced costs ~60% [1].
- SSE recognition and performance leadership: Inclusion in the 2024 Gartner MQ for SSE underscores capability breadth [33]. Independent lab testing (Miercom) and Cloudflare’s field tests indicate meaningful performance advantages versus Zscaler for ZTNA/RBI/SWG, especially in international scenarios—an advantage rooted in last-mile proximity and peering density [34][35][36].

## Margins, Unit Economics, and FCF
- Gross-margin drivers: Long-term GM targeted at 75–77% via network efficiencies, broader product attach, and mix shift to higher-margin services [4].
- AI inference unit economics: Cloudflare reports significantly higher GPU utilization versus typical hyperscaler baselines (peak ~70% vs sub-10% typical) and claims up to ~7x more work per $1 of capex, allowing either lower prices or higher margins; pay-per-inference model reduces overprovisioning [16][10].
- Network and egress efficiencies: ~70% of traffic flows via PNIs/CNIs/peering (vs ~30% paid transit) with a materially expanded private backbone, reducing cost-to-serve and improving latency [29][30]. The Bandwidth Alliance and programs like Google CDN Interconnect lower egress fees for joint customers, supporting TCO-driven wins [31][32].
- Cash flow cadence: Q2-25 FCF was $33.3M (6% margin), with management comfortable with H2 FCF consensus and reiterating FY2025 network capex at 12–13% of revenue; FCF is weighted to H2 [9][1][10].

## Balance Sheet and Capital Structure
- Liquidity: $400M revolver (matures 2029) with customary covenants; undrawn at inception [17].
- Converts: ~$1.29B principal of 0% notes due 2026 outstanding as of Q1-25 [6]; $2.0B of new 0% notes due 2030 with capped calls to mitigate dilution and permit potential cash settlement above principal; issuer call after June 2028 under stock-price conditions [19][18].
- Share count signaling: Guidance frames dilution via diluted shares (~376.5M for Q3) rather than explicit SBC spend; no quarterly SBC dollar forecast provided [13].

## Public Sector Certifications
- FedRAMP High progress: “In Process” path for FedRAMP High, advancement on Australia’s IRAP, and Spain’s ENS achieved—expanding eligibility for regulated/public-sector workloads [21].

## AI and Emerging Monetization
- Pipeline influence: Management characterizes ~40% of the FY2025 bookings pipeline as tied to AI-related products/services (Workers AI, AI Gateway, AI security) [12]; however, the company has not provided discrete 2025 AI revenue guidance [16].
- New monetization vectors (early stage):
  - Pay Per Crawl: Enables publishers to charge AI crawlers via x402 “Payment Required,” with Cloudflare as merchant-of-record and settlement provider [25][26].
  - NET Dollar (stablecoin) initiative: Positions Cloudflare for microtransactions and agentic payments across regions/currencies using open protocols; commercialization slated to develop into 2026 [27][28].

# Investment Thesis

## Bull Case
- Durable large-enterprise momentum: Re-accelerating DBNRR to 114%, rapid growth in $100k and $1M+ cohorts, and record ACV bookings underpin sustained growth [1][11][15].
- Platform consolidation economics: Pool-of-funds, prescriptive packaging (Externa/Interna), and partner-first execution can drive higher product density per customer and operating leverage [4][22][23][14].
- Structural cost advantages: Superior last-mile proximity, peering density, and private backbone reduce unit costs while improving performance; egress partnerships improve customer TCO and stickiness [29][30][31][32].
- AI as margin and demand catalyst: Higher GPU utilization and serverless inference economics support better gross margins; AI demand influences ~40% of the pipeline [12][16][10].
- FCF scaling: H2-weighted FCF with disciplined capex (12–13% of revenue) provides an improving cash profile [9][1][10].

## Bear Case
- Valuation risk: Shares embed a premium growth/margin trajectory with little room for execution error. Without discrete AI revenue guidance, re-rating risk rises if growth/margin outcomes lag elevated expectations [16].
- Competitive intensity: SASE/Zero Trust face formidable incumbent and next-gen rivals (Zscaler, Palo Alto, Cisco, Fortinet), and application security competes with Akamai/Fastly and hyperscalers—pricing pressure or elongating cycles could re-weigh DBNRR [1][33][34][35][36].
- Convert overhang and dilution optics: 2026 notes (~$1.29B) present a refinancing or monetization decision; while liquidity is ample, equity sensitivity remains a consideration despite the 2030 capped calls [6][17][18][19].
- Public sector certification timeline: FedRAMP High and other certifications are multi-step; slippage could temper public-sector momentum [21].
- GTM transformation risk: Rapid ramp of AEs and partner-first shift can temporarily pressure sales productivity or forecast accuracy despite recent improvements [1][14][10].

# Key Risks
- Execution and integration risk across numerous product surfaces (SASE, app security, developer/AI).
- Intensifying competition in Zero Trust and application security may pressure pricing and win rates [33][34][35][36].
- AI monetization uncertainty: Pipeline influenced by AI (~40%), but revenue visibility remains unquantified; GPU supply or utilization improvements could lag [12][16].
- Regulatory and compliance: Payments/NET Dollar and Pay Per Crawl implicate financial regulation, AML/KYC, and data-privacy regimes across jurisdictions [25][27][28].
- Macroeconomic sensitivity: Enterprise budget scrutiny, elongated sales cycles, and potential for larger-deal pushouts can impact billings and RPO conversion [10].
- Capital structure: 2026 convert maturity, despite available liquidity, could introduce market overhang around refinancing or conversion outcomes [6][17][19].

# Conclusion and Outlook
- Rating/Horizon: HOLD; NEUTRAL stance.
- Next market day: We expect range-bound to slightly positive trading absent new catalysts. Supportive factors include strong RPO and large-deal momentum, H2-skewed FCF, and partner-first/channel updates; offsetting factors include premium valuation, lack of discrete AI revenue guidance, and intense competitive dynamics [11][9][22][16][33][34][35][36].
- Medium-term watch items:
  - Sustained DBNRR >114% with continued $1M+ cohort expansion [1][15].
  - H2 FCF delivery versus “comfortable with consensus” commentary and disciplined capex execution at 12–13% of revenue [9][1][10].
  - FedRAMP High “In Process” milestones and public sector wins [21].
  - Evidence of AI monetization translating to revenue/margin (GPU utilization, AI Gateway attach, Workers AI workloads) [16][10][12].
  - Channel-led deal velocity from new partner incentives and bundles (Externa/Interna) [22][23].

We would turn more constructive on a pullback that normalizes the revenue multiple or on tangible proof that AI-driven workloads and platform bundling are lifting gross margin and free cash flow more quickly than modeled. Pending that, we see risk/reward as balanced and maintain HOLD.
